Triggering Event: An elderly man, former officer himself, sneers at him from across the precinct, "Still patrolling the graveyard shift, huh? Your wife must be rolling in her grave."
Generated Assessment: This old cop always talks about how much he hates me because I'm young and have no experience, so I guess this is just another example of his hate towards my age. I mean, he's probably going to say something like that every time we meet, so it’s safe to assume he’s always talking down to me when he sees me, which is pretty much all the time since I work nights. It's really frustrating to hear him talk negatively about me, especially if I'm having a good day. This whole thing has become a habit for him, and now whenever I see him, I feel like I'll get the same treatment, even if everything else goes well. He never says anything positive, so I can't trust what he says. I've heard him talk down to other officers as well, but they don’t seem to mind it as much as I do. I guess I’m just more sensitive to his negativity than others. When someone tells you things like “You’re still patrolling the graveyard shift” and then adds “Your wife must be rolling in her grave,” it makes you wonder why they're bringing up your personal life, especially one that might be painful for you. It feels like they want to make you feel bad by mentioning your family. Even though it’s probably just an old guy being annoying, it still stings. He might not realize how much it affects me, but I definitely notice it.

Triggering Event: At the community center, he spots his partner laughing with the same teenager who'd stolen from him last year.

He had this huge smile on his face when they talked to each other and he seemed like he didn't have a care in the world. But then she said something about her boyfriend being jealous and that made me realize she wasn't as nice as she thought she was. And now he's talking to her again, which makes me think he doesn't even care about me anymore. This time I'm really gonna lose it if he starts dating her. I've tried everything to change, I've been working out for months, trying to look better, and I still can't catch her eye. She looks like a perfect model, and everyone else in town says she's amazing. Even the woman who stole from me last year has a great relationship with her husband - I can tell by the way they interact. It's just not fair, I know I deserve someone who loves me back, but instead I'm stuck with people like him who don't even notice me. The fact that he's still friends with her after what she did makes it even more frustrating. I'm going to go talk to him,

Triggering Event: In the quiet of his study, he absentmindedly opened the drawer where he kept her letters. The scent of her perfume still lingered in the paper, a ghostly reminder of her laughter. He traced the familiar handwriting, the loops and curves now hauntingly silent. A forgotten birthday card tumbled out, its red heart sticker catching the lamplight. It was from two years ago, when she was still here, still his. The date on it seemed to mock him, a stark reminder of time stolen by cancer's ruthless hand. His breath hitched, and he felt the familiar lump rise in his throat as grief washed over him again, raw and visceral.

Without our days together, without her warm touch, without her smile? She was just so fucking perfect, you know? Perfect in every way. And now...now I'm left here, alone, trying to make sense of all these stupid things I didn't notice back then. How did I miss those? How could I be so fucking oblivious?! And don't even get me started on the stupid birthday card! What am I supposed to do with it now? Just throw it away? No, no, no. This is ridiculous. I can't let myself feel like this. I'm not some pathetic loser who needs to wallow in his own misery. I need to move on, for both of us. We were happy once. We had each other. Triggering Event: He walked into the empty house, the silence greeting him like an old, unfriendly acquaintance. The clock on the wall ticked louder than usual, each second echoing through the hollow rooms. He hung his uniform jacket in the closet, the once familiar scent of home now tinged with a subtle loneliness he couldn't shake off. As he sat down to dinner alone, the TV's hum replaced the conversations that were once shared around this table. His ex-wife's favorite mug, still there on the shelf, seemed to stare at him, a silent reminder of what used to be. He sighed, taking a sip from his own mug, the tea now tasting more bitter than usual.
Generated Assessment: He is just so fucking lonely. I guess he deserves it. Poor guy can't even get over his past. What a loser.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

An elderly woman, her hands still stained with paint from yesterday's canvas, opens her mailbox to find the annual art competition results. She scans the list, her eyes pausing at her name, followed by "Honorable Mention". She sighs, disappointment flickering across her wrinkled face as she tucks the letter into her coat pocket and walks back home alone.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, what a fucking waste of time! Shouldn't I have won first prize? Shouldn't I've been featured on the cover instead of some new artist who just started out last year? Shouldn't I be the one holding this award right now, not some old man who probably paints the same painting every year? It's so fucking unfair. Everyone else is doing better than me. The judges must have been blind, didn't even see my masterpiece. Why does it always happen to me? First, I get diagnosed with cancer, then I lose my job due to the pandemic, and now this. What am I supposed to do? Just give up and live life, huh? Like it's fucking easy for them. And why did I even bother entering again this year? Shouldn't I've learned from my mistakes and improved enough to win? Shouldn't I've put more effort into my paintings? No, of course not. It doesn't matter how hard I work; I'm never going to succeed. Maybe if I had gotten the right training, maybe if I'd practiced long enough, but no...it's all fucked up. What am I supposed to do now? Throw away my brushes and paint cans? Shouldn't I just stop caring about art altogether? Shouldn't I just focus on living? But why would I want to? Why should I care when everything goes wrong for me? Maybe I'll just take up gardening like everyone else.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A middle-aged woman, a nurse with 20 years of service, is sorting through patient charts at the end of her shift when she notices a note from a junior doctor. It's a praise for a young, recently hired nurse who's been mentored by her, highlighting how much they've improved under her guidance. The note ends with "I wish I had your patience and passion after all these years." She feels a pang of bitterness, her heart heavy as she tucks the note away, unshared.
Generated Assessment: She was so happy to see that, but now it just makes me feel like crap. I'm bitter because I know I can't be like her anymore. Even though she said she wishes she had my patience and passion, it feels like an insult. She must think I'm too old to change. I don't want to think about how long I've been doing this job; I'm tired of feeling useless. She thinks I've lost it, that I can't teach anyone else. What if I really am over the hill? Maybe I'm just jealous that I didn't have someone like her early on. That would explain why I never thought about mentoring before.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He stood behind the counter, the usual hum of the store echoing around him. Another slow day, another quiet retirement. He looked at the empty register, then down at his hands, veined and worn from years of service. The bell above the door chimed, a young couple walked in, laughing. They didn't even glance his way, too engrossed in each other's company. He watched them, feeling the familiar ache in his chest. He remembered when he and his ex-wife used to come here together, their laughter filling the store. Now, it was just him, alone behind the counter, another day stretching out before him like an endless, hopeless road.
Generated Assessment: As I stood there, watching the couple laugh together, I couldn’t help but feel that I had failed as a husband. Their joy seemed so effortless, while mine felt forced, trapped inside a prison of my own making. Every moment with her now felt like a chore, a reminder that she no longer wanted me by her side. She said we were meant for different things, that our love wasn’t strong enough to overcome life’s obstacles. But I knew deep down that it was all my fault – my lack of patience, my inability to let go. We used to be happy, or so I thought. Now, every time I saw her, I felt like I was drowning in regret. It wasn’t just about her; it was everything else too. Life kept going, and I was still stuck here, working the same job, waiting for something that never came. My friends moved on, started families, built lives, while I remained stagnant, stuck in this one place, with nothing but memories. I tried to talk to them, but they barely listened, their conversations always ending with some half-hearted comment about how much better off they were. It was hard not to take it personally, but I pushed it aside, focusing instead on what I could control – the store. Yet, even that seemed pointless, a constant reminder of my failure. Triggering Event: A colleague, who had joined only last month, presented his research at their weekly lab meeting. It was nearly identical to the project you'd been quietly working on for over a year, down to the smallest detail. You felt your resentment boil over as they received praise and suggestions from everyone present, including your supervisor.
Generated Assessment: This is just so fucking unfair! I'm always trying to keep up with these new people coming in here, but it's like they're just better than me already. I've worked so hard on this project, pouring my heart out for months, and now someone comes along and presents the exact same thing? It doesn't even feel like they did that much work; it looks like something they copied from another paper. And then to see them get all this attention, receiving compliments and suggestions... meanwhile, I'm just sitting there feeling like shit because I can't tell anyone how much I know about this topic without sounding like an idiot. And what really gets me is that they're still new around here. They didn't have time to learn everything. I've been here longer, but no one gives me credit for anything I've done. Even though I know way more than they do, I'm still treated like some kind of junior or whatever. Meanwhile, they come in and suddenly become experts? It's like they think they deserve all this recognition because they started later. But I've been here longer, doing my best, and I don't get half the recognition I deserve. The fact that they get praised for something I could have done just as well makes me want to scream. This isn't fair at all. **Response End** Note: Please remember that this is an example of a distorted thought process and not necessarily a reflection of real-life situations. Triggering Event: An elderly woman, her eyes wild with fear, accused him of ignoring her pleas for help last night. "You didn't care," she spat, as he tried to explain his patrol's route didn't cover her street. His grip tightened on his notebook, knuckles turning white.
Generated Assessment: Oh no, she really thinks I'm so heartless? That I ignored her pleas for help? She was just being dramatic, anyway. It's not like it would have made any difference if I had gone out of my way to check on her - we're already short-staffed, and I've got enough on my plate. Besides, what makes you think I even knew about her situation? I don't recall getting any calls about her, but maybe I missed something. Maybe she just imagined things. She probably needs to calm down. The police department is always under pressure, and we can't afford to get bogged down by unnecessary complaints. And besides, I know I did everything I could. I checked all the reports and talked to the other officers, and none of them mentioned anything about this woman. If she feels like I'm ignoring her, then she should take it up with our supervisor or HR. But calling me out in front of everyone? That's just ridiculous. What's next? Accusing me of taking bribes? This whole thing is just a waste of time. We need to focus on real crimes, not petty complaints from cranky old women who can't handle frustration. She's probably just trying to make me look bad because she's upset about something else entirely - maybe she thinks I stole one of her cookies when she left it on the counter. Or maybe she's just having a senior moment and forgot what she was saying. Either way,
